Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Signal-Amplification for Instrument-Free, Multiplexed Immunoassay - a Generalized Platform for Biosening

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET - 1510468 Lei, Yu

The PI has proposed a novel biological assay that can be visualized (instead of instrument) for detecting pathogenic bacteria and biomolecules that indicate disease state. If successful, it could be used in the food industry, water quality monitoring and medical diagnostics.

A modified Enzyme-Linked Immuno-Sorbent Assays (ELISAs) which would be visual (instead of an instrument) and is expected to have good sensitivity, simplified procedure, lower cost, and allows for the facile simultaneous detection of multiple targets. Intellectual Merit: A simple but potentially very powerful amplification and instrument-free biosensing technology based on visual height measurement with excellent simplicity, portability, sensitivity, and adaptability will be developed.
In lieu of an enzyme the detection antibody is modified with self-assembled lipid-based nanoparticles (NPs). After a washing-step the assay tubes are loaded with a triblock polymer solution followed by dyed lipid-based NPs that self- aggregate. After the precipitation of dyed NP clusters by gravity, the visual height of dyed NPs clusters is expected to show concentration-dependent behavior, due to the difference in the surface-bound clusters resulting from targets captured by the conjugated antibody on the tube inner surface. By using multiple tubes, each coated with specific antibodies in series, multiple targets can be detected simultaneously. Broader Impacts: Positive research outcome will potentially impact positively on public health, especially for remote and low-resource regions. This project will also positively impact education of the graduate, undergraduate and high school students by integrating advanced nano-biosensing into their educational and laboratory training. Interaction with the general public (through Connecticut Science Center and focus conference sessions) and industry companies will enable broader dissemination of the results. Two new courses (Special topics in Bioanalytical Sensor and Nanostructure Characterization) will be offered to UConn students in Fall 2016. The graduate students to be recruited on this project will actively interact with UConn Tech Plaza to learn about entrepreneurship and spin off a start-up company if any promising IP emerges in this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Enzyme-Linked ImmunoSorbent Assays (ELISAs) are the most common techniques employed to detect the presence of biomolecules such as protein biomarkers, viruses and bacteria. In traditional ELISAs, an enzyme linked to the detection antibody catalyzes a chromogenic reaction that brings about signal amplification. Notwithstanding its ubiquity, they typically require advanced instruments for measurement, tedious procedures for signal amplification, and/or the requirement of skillful personnel to perform the complicated procedures, which greatly limit its broader applications in low-resource countries. Hence, a user-friendly, sensitive and simplified immunosensor platform is essential for the preventions of disease outbreaks.

In this project, we aim at developing an instrument-free, user friendly immunobiosensor which has good sensitivity, simplified procedure, and lower costs.  Several signal amplification techniques based on the aggregation of liposomes or liposomes with entrapped enzymes have been developed and evaluated for naked-eye based detection without using advanced instrument. Through these studies, this project provides insights on the understanding of the polymer and lipid interaction and its effect on liposomes clustering efficiency, and the design of naked-eye based, advanced-instrument-free immunosensing device, thus paving the roads for future development of low-cost immunobiosensor.

This project not only generates new scientific knowledge, but also positively impacts education of the involved students by integrating advanced nano-biosensing into their educational and laboratory training. Through this project, many graduate and undergraduate students, including those from traditionally underrepresented group, have been provided with research opportunities, thus training and attracting more students to work in science and engineering. This project also led to conferences contribution, journal publication and interaction with general public, thus broadening the impact of the outcomes.
